channel.title: Applied Data Science & Artificial Intelligence
channel.description: Recent content on Applied Data Science & Artificial Intelligence

item.title: Adsai Open Day 2024
item.description: Embark on Your AI Journey: Discover the ADSAI Open Day 2024! Are you ready to take the next step in your journey towards becoming a leader in the exciting world of artificial intelligence (AI)? Join us for the ADSAI (Applied Data Science and Artificial Intelligence) Open Day 2024, an event designed specifically for young master’s students like you who are eager to explore the endless possibilities of AI research.

item.title: ADSAI open day 2024!
item.description: Embark on Your AI Journey: Discover the ADSAI Open Day 2024! Are you ready to take the next step in your journey towards becoming a leader in the exciting world of artificial intelligence (AI)? Join us for the ADSAI (Applied Data Science and Artificial Intelligence) Open Day 2024, an event designed specifically for young master’s students like you who are eager to explore the endless possibilities of AI research.

item.title: Alejandro Rodriguez Garcia
item.description: Since 2022 he is an assistant professor at the University of Trieste. Previously he was the “Ludwig Boltzmann” Senior Postdoctoral Fellow at the Condensed Matter and Statistical Physics section at the International Center for Theoretical Physics (ICTP), a postdoctoral fellow at the International School for Advanced Studies (SISSA), and a professional researcher at the Università Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC).

item.title: Fabio Anselmi
item.description: Fabio received the B.S. and M.S. degrees in theoretical physics from the University of Padova, in 2000 and the Ph.D. degree in quantum physics from Hertfordshire University, UK, in 2004.During 2020-2022, he was an Assistant Professor at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, Texas. He is currently Senior Researcher at the University of Trieste, Italy.

item.title: ADSAI Open Day
item.description: ADSAI 2023 Open day The ADSAI 2023 Open Day is an opportunity to meet, in person or online, the ADSAI faculty. Join us to see a presentation of the ADSAI PhD program, with talks from the ADSAI director and the coordinators of the three main ADSAI curricula, as well as to meet students that will discuss their PhD at ADSAI.

item.title: Alessio Ansuini
item.description: Dr Ansuini graduated in Physics from Sapienza University of Rome and obtained a PhD in Physics in the same University (2010). He worked in SISSA as a postdoc in several groups (Neurobiology and Cognitive Neuroscience sector) on the analysis of experimental data with machine learning and deep learning models. Since 2019 he works in Area Science Park as a Research Technologist and since 2020 he teaches the course of Deep Learning in the Master in Data Science and Scientific Computing (DSSC).

item.title: Alexandro Saro
item.description: Alex Saro graduated in Physics from the University of Trieste (2003 and 2006), and obtained a PhD in Physics from the University of Trieste (2009). He worked as a Senior Research Scientist at Ludwig Maximilian of Munich from 2010 and 2017, where he moved as Ricercatore di II livello (equivalent of associate professor) at INAF - Trieste.

item.title: Stefano Cozzini
item.description: Dr. Cozzini is presently the director of the Institute of Research and Technology (RET) at Area Science Park where he is managing all the scientific infrastructures of the campus, including a NGS platform and the ORFEO HPC/AI data center. He teaches HPC topics at DSSC and MHPC and is currently involved in several National and European projects on the above topic.

item.title: Antonio Celani
item.description: Antonio Celani earned his PhD at Politecnico di Torino, Italy in 1998. After post-doctoral fellowships at Max Planck Institute in Munich and at the Observatoire de la Côte d’Azur he became researcher for the French National Research Council (CNRS) in 2000. In 2007 he joined the Institut Pasteur Paris as a research director where he started working at the interface between physics and biology.

item.title: Andrea De Lorenzo
item.description: Andrea De Lorenzo is assistant professor at the University of Trieste. His research interests include evolutionary computation, application of machine learning techniques to engineering, computer security problems, information extraction and natural language processing. He won the silver medal at the 13th Human-Competitive Awards, 2016, for Human-Competitive Results produced by Genetic and Evolutionary Computation.

item.title: Applied operations research
item.description: Example terms related to Applied operations research: Smart cities, transportation and logistics, productivity analyisis and performance evaluation

item.title: Artificial Intelligence and society
item.description: Example terms related to Etichs of Artificial Intelligence: Responsible innovation, science diplomacy, science and technology studies and public engagement.

item.title: Bayesian statistics
item.description: Example terms related to Bayesian statistics: Markov models, Montecarlo sampling and variational inference.

item.description: Example terms related to Biology: Computational biology, biomarkers and diseases modelling.

item.description: Example terms related to Business intelligence: Decision support systems.

item.title: Causal inference
item.description: Example terms related to Causal inference: Intervention and counterfactual models.

item.title: Computational intelligence
item.description: Example terms related to Computational intelligence: Genetic programming,Evolutionary computation and bio-inspired computation.

item.title: Control theory
item.description: Example terms related to Control theory: Optimal and constrained control.

item.description: Example terms related to Earth sciences: Oceanography, geology, vulcanology.

item.description: Example terms related to Environmental sciences: Biodiversity measuring and indexes

item.title: Epidemiology
item.description: Example terms related to Epidemiology: Computational models of human behaviour and viral diffusion.

item.description: Example terms related to Explanaible Artificial Intelligence: Bias detection, explanation of black-box models, formal methods in AI

item.title: Frequentist statistics
item.description: Example terms related to Frequentist statistics: Null hypothesis, multiple-testing, false discovery and familywise error rates.

item.title: Genomics
item.description: Example terms related to Genomics: Statistical models for next-generation sequencing technologies.

item.title: Healthcare
item.description: Example terms related to Healthcare: Biostatistics, telemedicine and electronic health records.

item.description: Example terms related to Unsupervised learning: Clustering, dimensionality reduction

item.title: Francesco Pauli
item.description: Francesco Pauli is full professor of Statistics at the Deaprtment of Economics, Business, Mathematics and Statistics of the University of Trieste since 2021. Previously he has been associate professor at the University of Trieste and Researcher at the universities of Trieste and Padova. He obtained a PhD in Statitics from the University of Padova in 2000.

item.title: Alberto D'Onofrio
item.description: Dr d’Onofrio works at the interface between Informatics, Physics and Applied Mathematics. He graduated in Electrical Engineering at Pisa University (1993), and got a PhD in ‘Medical Computer Sciences’ at the Roma Sapienza University (2000). He has been PostDoc, Researcher (2003) and Group Leader (2008) at the European Institute of Oncology, Milan.

item.title: Eric Medvet
item.description: Eric Medvet is an Associate Professor in Computer Engineering at the Department of Engineering and Architecture of University of Trieste, Italy. He founded and leads the Evolutionary Robotics and Artificial Life lab (ERALlab); he is the co-founder and co-head of the Machine Learning Lab. His research activities include evolutionary computation, artificial life, embodied intelligence, and machine learning applications.

item.title: Felice Andrea Pellegrino
item.description: Felice Andrea Pellegrino is Associate Professor of Automatica at the Department of Engineering and Architecture, University of Trieste, where he teaches Control Theory and Computer Vision. He has been Research Fellow at SISSA and University of Udine. He is Associate Editor of the IEEE Control Systems Letters and member of the Conference Editorial Boards of the IEEE Control Systems Society and of the European Control Association.

item.title: Sara Marceglia
item.description: Sara Marceglia is Professor of eHealth at the University of Trieste. Her research interests regard the development of personalized applications, decision support systems, and telemedicine systems for fragile patients, with particular attention to neurologic patients. She works to implement integrated systems for chronic patients’ management, including cloud-based data collection platforms, big data analytics infrastructures, ecosystems of personalized app for Patient Reported Outcome collection, and wearable non-stigmatizing telemonitoring devices.

item.title: Luca Manzoni
item.description: Luca Manzoni is an assistant professor (associate professor from July 2022) in the field of Evolutionary Computation, Artificial Intelligence, and Natural Computing. He received multiple awards for his research work, he is currently an associate editor of Swarm and Evolutionary Computation. In the last five years he held courses from the bachelor to the PhD level on the topics of algorithms, computational complexity, computer architectures, operating systems, information retrieval, and evolutionary computation.

item.title: Leonardo Egidi
item.description: Dr Egidi graduated in Statistics from the University of Trieste (2011 and 2014), and obtained a PhD in Statistics from the University of Padova (2018). Since 2020 he is an Assistant Professor of Statistics at the University of Trieste. He regularly teaches Bayesian inference and statistical methods, and is interested in computational statistics and its applications to biostatistics, social sciences and sport analytics.

item.title: Domenico De Stefano
item.description: Domenico De Stefano obtained his PhD in Statistics from the University of Naples Federico II in 2009. Since 2020, he is Full Professor of Social Statistics at the University of Trieste. His teaching activities are in the field of statistics, survey methods and network analysis. His research interests mainly focus on social network analysis and statistical modelling, with particular attention to the development of new methodological tools to explore relational data.

item.title: Daniele Coslovich
item.description: Prof. Coslovich is Associate Professor at the Physics Department of the University of Trieste since 2020. Previously, he worked at the University of Montpellier and at the Technical University of Vienna. His research interests focus on the theoretical and computational modelling of disordered systems and soft materials. He also contributes to several open source packages for molecular simulations and data analysis.

item.title: Lorenzo Castelli
item.description: Prof. Lorenzo Castelli graduated in Electronic Engineering (1997) from the University of Trieste and holds a PhD in Transportation (2002) from the same university. Since 2019 he’s associate professor in Operations Research. His research activity focusses on productivity analysis and mathematical optimisation applied to logistics and transport, with emphasis on various aspects of air traffic management, including market-based mechanisms for slot allocation and pricing mechanisms to redistribute traffic across the European air network.

item.title: Luca Bortolussi
item.description: Luca Bortolussi is full professor of computer science at the University of Trieste. He obtained a phd in computer science from the university of Udine in 2007, and after that worked in Trieste, with periods spent in the School of Informatics of the University of Edinburgh and in the Faculty of Informatics of Saarland University in Saarbruecken.

item.title: Nicola Torelli
item.description: Nicola Torelli is full professor of Statistics at the University of Trieste. He currently teaches various courses related to Statistical Inference, Statistical Learning Techniques and Statistical Methods for Data Science at undergraduate, MSc and PhD level. He has been President of the Italian Statistical Society and currently is the coordinator of the Statistics and Data Science Group of the Italian Statistical Society.

item.title: Giulia Bernardini
item.description: Dr. Bernardini received her M.Sc. in Mathematics from the University of Pisa in 2017, and obtained a Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Milano-Bicocca in 2021, winning the Best Italian Ph.D. Thesis in Theoretical Computer Science prize, awarded by the Italian Chapter of EATCS. She spent one year as a Postdoc researcher at the Centrum Wiskunde en Informatica in Amsterdam, and she is an Assistant Professor at the University of Trieste since January 2022.

item.title: Marco Barchiesi
item.description: Since October 2019, I am associate professor of probability at the Department of Mathematics and Geosciences of the University of Trieste. I spent most of my career, from October 2010 to September 2019, at the University of Naples Federico II, first as ERC postdoc, then as assistant professor, and finally as associate professor in mathematical analysis.

item.title: Stefano Martellos
item.description: Stefano Martellos is associate professor of systematic botany at the Dept. of Life Sciences of the University of Trieste. He obtained a phd in Environmental botanyfrom the university of Trieste. His research interests ranges among the diverse aspects of Biodiversity Informatics, and their application in several fields, from the digitization of natural history colletions to supporting citizen science activities.

item.title: Sylvio Barbon Jr
item.description: Sylvio is an Associate Professor at the Department of Engineering and Architecture at the University of Trieste (UNITS) and part of the Machine Learning Lab. Previously, he was the leader of the research group that studies machine learning at the State University of Londrina (UEL), Brazil. He received his BSc degree in Computer Science in 2005, MSc degree in Computational Physics from the University of São Paulo (2007), a degree in Computational Engineering in 2008, and PhD degree (2011) from IFSC/USP.

item.title: Giulia Barbati
item.description: G. Barbati graduated in Statistics from University of Rome (1999) and obtained a PhD in Functional Neuroimaging from University of Chieti-Pescara (2007). Since 2019, she is Associate Professor in Medical Statistics at University of Trieste. She works on survival analysis methods and joint models for longitudinal and time-to-event data. Moreover, she is interested in statistical methods for exploiting informational content of health administrative data and in machine learning (ML) algorithms for risk prediction.

item.title: Simone Arnaldi
item.description: Simone Arnaldi graduated in International relations and diplomacy (2000) from the University of Trieste, and obtained a PhD from the Pontifical Gregorian University (2005). He is Associate Professor of Sociology at the University of Trieste. He studies the governance of science, technology, and innovation (STI) governance, with a focus on responsibility in STI and on science diplomacy.

item.title: Giulio Caravagna
item.description: Since 2020, Giulio leads the Cancer Data Science Laboratory at the University of Trieste, a group of interdisciplinary scientists working at the intersection of computational and experimental research, approaching real-world biological questions with state-of-the-art Machine Learning. Giulio trained in computer science at the University of Pisa; after a PhD (2011), he carried out postdoctoral training in mathematical models for biology at Milan-Bicocca, in machine learning for biology at the University of Edinburgh , and in evolutionary cancer genomics at the Institute of Cancer Research.

item.title: Advanced topics in network analysis: theory and applications
item.description: Network analysis is a set of statistical techniques focused on uncovering and modeling patterns of relationships that arise from the interactions of people, groups, organizations, or any other entities. Network analysis is an in-demand approach to data analysis because it identifies underlying structures within data characterized by complex dependence structures. This short course will examine the most recent developments in statistical methods for analyzing and modeling the structure and dynamics of complex networks.

item.title: Advanced topics in Reinforcement Learning
item.description: This short course will address issues in Multi-agent reinforcement learning, from Markov games and the connection with game theory to multi-armed bandit algorithms.

item.title: Advanced topics in statistical modeling
item.description: The course extends basic statistical models through the introduction of multilevel/ hierarchical models, semi and non-parametric regression models, spline functions, penalized likelihood approaches (such as LASSO and Ridge regression models), and hierarchical models for estimating smooth regression functions. Applications to complex datasets and simulation approaches will be illustrated during the course through the use of the Stan ecosystem and the statistical software R.

item.title: Application
item.description: Who can apply Candidates must have acquired a “Laurea magistrale” or equivalent foreign title (giving access to the Doctoral program in the country in which it is issued) by October, 31st 2022 When and how to apply The application must be submitted through the on line procedure at (https://esse3.units.it/Home.do) by 13:00 of June, 27th 2022

item.title: Artificial Intelligence in society
item.description: Artificial intelligence (AI) holds the promise of advancing society in a number of ways. At the same time, AI is increasingly implicated in controversies around its applications. Such an ambivalent public image of AI has led scientific societies, firms, governments and regulators to become more active in issuing blueprints, strategies, and regulations aimed at steering AI towards desirable social goals, while averting negative impacts on society.

item.title: Biodiversity Informatics
item.description: The course aims at providing basic knowledge to organize, manage, and use biodiversity databases, both at management and research level. Furthermore, it aims at providing knowledge to support students in the drafting of research projects and proposals. Specifically, the course will provide: knowledge of the different types of data that exist in the field of biodiversity; understanding of the modern approached form digitizing, aggregating, and managing different types of biodiversity data; understanding of species distribution models; knowledge of the main tools for the production of interactive digital identification keys, and understanding of their logic.

item.title: Cookie Policy
item.description: This page outlines the cookie policy in use in this website along with details of cookies used by the website. This information may change over time and the latest version can be found at this page. Most websites you visit use cookies. Cookies are small text files containing small amounts of information which are downloaded to your device when you visit a website.

item.title: Copula modeling – Extreme value theory
item.description: The course will give a brief introduction to univariate methods for extreme value modeling (generalized Pareto distribution, Poisson point process) with and without covariates. The course will offer a basic introduction to copulas for dependence modelling and their main properties, along with the most important theoretical results. Applications to relevant fields will be illustrated: computation of Value at Risk in finance; Risk Aggregation; Financial time series modelling with copulas.

item.title: Courses
item.description: The ADSAI PhD program offers different types of training courses, some of them offered in collaboration with the Theoretical and Scientific Data Science (TSDS) PhD program at SISSA, as well as with the Master in Data Science and Scientific Computing (DSSC) at the University of Trieste. Following regulations regarding the university educational credits (CFU) system, every year ADSAI students need to define a training program in collaboration wiht their supervisors; the program can involve ADSAI courses, partner courses and attendance to conferences/ schools.

item.title: Curricula at ADSAI
item.description: The ADSAI faculty and students are divided into three curricula: Industry and natural sciences, coordinated by Prof. Luca Bortolussi; Life sciences and medicine, coordinated by Prof. Giulia Barbati; Economy and society, coordinated by Prof. Domenico De Stefano.

item.title: Economy and society
item.description: Description Introduction The economy and society curriculum concerns data science and artificial intelligence methods applied to the broad area of social sciences as well as the social impact of their applications. The last decades have witnessed the growing accessibility and availability of large and heterogeneous data sources, and an increasing development of computational tools for social data analysis and modelling.

item.title: Evolutionary Robotics
item.description: The course introduces the main concepts of evolutionary robotics, that is, the family of optimization techniques based on the paradigm of natural evolution (evolutionary computation) and the principle of embodied cognition. Moreover, it surveys recent and significant research works on evolutionary robotics, highlighting their methodological aspects and their potential applicability to other domains.

item.title: Explainable AI
item.description: The course on explainable artificial intelligence deals with the hot topic of identifying either efficient models that are also human comprehensible or to build explanations from highly efficient but black-box deep learning models. We will describe from a high level perspective the different approaches for deep learning models (e.g. local and global approximations/distillations and feature ranking) and also introduce some ideas from neuro-symbolic computing, attempting to combine logic and deep learning.

item.title: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)
item.description: The FAQs are intended for both students and potential sponsors of ADSAI fellowships. For any question not already covered in thes FAQs, please contact the ADSAI PhD coordinator. Governance What is the official ADSAI teaching language? All of ADSAI teaching is in English. What is the official ADSAI teaching language?

item.title: Home
item.description: Mission Across all fields, technological development is fostering the collection of large amounts of complex datasets that require advanced data science skills to be organised, processed and successfully mined. Without novel machine learning methods able to interpret and extract knowledge from those datasets, our capacity to understand the world is severely limited.

item.title: How to Apply to ADSAI
item.description: 2023 applications As in 2022 there will be two rounds of admissions for the 2023 ADSAI PhD program. Both will be completed before October 2023, as the new PhD cohort will officially start on November 1st 2023. The panels evaluating applicant across both rounds will be likely different, and you can apply multiple times if you wish so.

item.title: Industry, transportation, and natural sciences
item.description: Description Introduction Data Science and Artificial Intelligence are driving the digital transformation of industries, transportation, and cities. The pace of innovation in these areas is continuously reshaping the scientific and industrial scene, constantly creating new opportunities and research questions. Their impact ranges from smart management of production lines to adaptive approaches in logistic and supply chains and to autonomous driving vehicles.

item.title: Law and AI
item.description: The course on ‘Law and AI’ focuses on how current and prospective legal rules constrain and govern data science and AI applications, especially in the European legal framework. The course will explore the general legal requirements currently applicable to data science and AI applications in Europe, as well as the ongoing debate on prospective legal measures that could in the future apply in the field.

item.title: Medicine, Life Sciences, and Environment
item.description: Description Introduction Life Sciences, broadly including Medicine, Healthcare and Public Health Sciences, drive conception and development of technologies that in the last decades have been impacting our society the most. The general context is to understand complex biological phenomena, measure the effect of therapeutical interventions on single patients and across the population and enhance our ability to predict disease trajectories in single individuals, as well as in the broader society.

item.title: MISSION
item.description: Mission Across all fields, technological development is fostering the collection of large amounts of complex datasets that require advanced data science skills to be organised, processed and successfully mined. Without novel machine learning methods able to interpret and extract knowledge from those datasets, our capacity to understand the world is severely limited.

item.title: Optimization-based control
item.description: The course on ‘Optimization-based control’ will deal with optimization applied to control of linear, possibly constrained, discrete-time dynamical systems. After an introduction to the linear discrete-time dynamical systems and a survey of the relevant basic results of systems theory, the focus will be on (i) How to employ optimization to get open-loop optimal control sequences,(ii) How to get closed-loop control laws from open-loop control sequences, (iii) How to employ online optimization to control dynamical systems; (iv) How to employ optimization to get open-loop optimal control sequences in a model-free, data-driven fashion.

item.title: Population-based Optimisation Methods
item.description: The course “Population-based Optimization Methods” focuses on a collection of methods, generally inspired by natural phenomena, used for optimization and where multiple solutions to the same problems are iteratively improved. In this course we will explore genetic algorithms, genetic programming, evolution strategies, particle swarm optimization, differential evolution, how to represent particular problem domains (e.

item.title: Review of statistical modeling and inference
item.description: The course is aimed at reviewing the fundamentals of statistical theory within the classical statistical paradigm. We review the whole setting of likelihood theory, with a special focus on maximum likelihood estimation, properties of maximum likelihood estimators and a brief review of hypothesis testing. We deepen then linear and generalized linear models, covering the basic theory of these modeling techniques, the main inferential tools and proposing applications with real and complex data.

item.title: Statistical methods for clinical prediction models and causal inference
item.description: In this course, we will briefly introduce the principal study designs in epidemiology and clinical research. Then, according to the objectives of the study, we will describe the statistical approaches underlying the two main aims in health research, i.e. predicting prognosis and estimating the causal effect of specific exposures on the outcomes.

item.title: Students
item.description: 2021 Cohort Student Email Bachelor of Science Master of Science ADSAI supervisor(s) External supervisors Topic Alice Antonello alice.antonello@phd.units.it Biotechnology (University of Turin) Quantitative and Computational Biology (University of Trento) Giulio Caravagna Computational methods for tumor evolution Giovanni Baj giovanni.baj@phd.units.it Physics (University of Insubria) Physics (University of Insubria) Giulia Barbati Arjuna Scagnetto (ASUGI) Applications of AI in Health Care Lorenzo Basile lorenzo.

item.title: The ADSAI PhD program
item.description: “Artificial Intelligence is the new electricity.” Andrew Ng, Co-founder and lead of Google Brain. The Applied Data Science and Artificial Intelligence (ADSAI) PhD program at the Univeristy of Trieste started with the 2021 cohort, and since 2021 ADSAI is also part of the Italian National PhD program in Artificial Intelligence.
